description: woven rain cape with crescent bib, with indigo dyed linear pattern; dark fringe cascading down from bib; ties at top and woven straps at PL and PR sides
medium: Rice straw, bark, cotton; indigo dye
text: This style of straw coat (mino) was worn by residents of northern Japan to protect themselves from heavy rain and snowfall. A man made this fancy rain cape (date-gera) as a gift for his wife or fiancée to wear with pride to festive occasions. He used rice straw left over from rice cultivation and cotton for the oval-shaped shoulder piece, attaching a fringe of shredded tree bark strands along the edge. Further north, on Hokkaido, the indigenous Ainu would refine and spin material like this from elm bark’s inner layer to weave into cloth.
title: Festive rain cape (date-gera) made in Aomori Prefecture
